Black hair coat is dominant over white hair coat. Three quarters of the offspring have black coats, and one quarter have white coats. The genotypes of the parents were most likely

A. Bb × Bb

B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

C. bb × Bb

D. bb × bb

E. bb × BB

F. Bb × bb

G. Bb × BB

H. BB × Bb

I. BB × bb

J. BB × BB

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb.
